title: Dina Asher-Smith makes history at World Championships despite last-minute scare
text:

Dina Asher-Smith overcame a “last-second” scare to help herself to another slice of history with sprint relay silver last night, writes Alex Spink in Doha.

Speed demon Dina, already the first British female sprinter to win a global title, added another first by winning her third medal at a single world championships.

No athlete from these shores, male or female, had ever achieved that, and it seemed fate would conspire against her in her bid when team mate Imani Lansiquot dropped out five minutes before they were called onto the track.

“It was a last-second change,” revealed the Kent star after Britain finished second behind Jamaica in 41.85 seconds.

(Image: Getty)

“We made the decision to run a different team just before the call room - and almost ran a pb without practicing any of the changes in the warm-up area.”

Asher-Smith had refused to get carried away celebrating either her 200 metres gold or 100m silver for fear of letting down her team mates.

That focus paid dividends as she switched from anchor leg in the emergency reshuffle, took the baton from lead-off runner Asha Philip and set up Ashleigh Nelson and Daryl Neita to repeat Britain’s silver success of two years ago.

(Image: PA)

Asher-Smith’s composure under pressure showed how far she had come since making her senior championships debut in the same event at the 2013 Worlds in Moscow.

That night in the Luzhniki Stadium she was “literally so scared, holding the baton with hands so sweaty I thought it would fall out”.

She ended up with a bronze medal around her neck but vowing “never to be that unprepared and nervous” again - and she never has.

(Image: AFP via Getty Images)

So much so that this was her fifth medal in four world championships, moving her to within three of Sir Mo Farah’s all-time best British tally.

When told her three-medal haul was unprecedented, the 23-year old said: “I did not know that but in all honesty that wouldn’t even be a conceivable idea if not for the team work.

“The relay is a team event. You can’t do that on your own. So thank you ladies.”

(Image: REUTERS)

Neita added: “Dina knows how proud we are. She’s been doing her thing since day one. She’s killing it, she’s smashing it. Onto next year and bigger and better things.”

Asked what it would take to turn silver into Olympic gold, Philip replied: “Not much clearly if we’ve just changed the team five minutes before!

“We’re talented. Best believe that gold is coming. For now we’ll let them Jamaica have it and we can have it in a year’s time.”

(Image: Getty Images)

Britain gave up their men’s world sprint relay crown - but it took the third fastest run in history to deny them.

Adam Gemili and Nethaneel Mitchell-Blake had come to Qatar firmly believing they would retain the title they won in London.

And with Zharnel Hughes and Richard Kilty joining them their optimism was well-paced as they smashed the European record with a 37.36secs run.

(Image: PA)

But on the night it was not enough as they came up against an inspired American team on a mission to avenge the beating they took two years ago.

“Sometimes you have to hold up your hands,” said Gemili, after the US quartet clocked 37.10secs to break their own national record.

“We ran a British record and pushed for the gold but the Americans were better than us.”

(Image: AFP/Getty)

But Kilty added: “It took the third fastest time ever to beat us. We can get gold in Tokyo.”

The two faster relays in history unsurprisingly both belong to Jamaican teams featuring Usain Bolt.

Who know what time Britain might have managed had not Hughes torn his hamstring on the second leg.

“When I handed the baton, I pulled it,” he said. “But I had to give it to Richard whatever because tonight was about getting a medal.

“The guys the glory I have, the fight which is inside me, I did my best. We are going home with something around our necks.”
description: Kent rocket becomes first Briton ever to win three medals at a single world championships
